claim:
Consider the following background information: A 14-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and is found on ultrasound to have a gallstone. Based on clinical suspicion, a CBC, a Coombs test, and a bilirubin panel are obtained to determine the etiology of the gallstone. These tests reveal a mild normocytic anemia with associated reticulocytosis as well as an increased RDW. In addition there is an indirect hyperbilirubinemia and the Coombs test results are negative. To confirm the diagnosis, an osmotic fragility test is performed which shows increased fragility in hypotonic solution.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: In this patient, if a blood smear were obtained, findings of dacrocytes would most likely be anticipated.

supporting.text: The clinical presentation and lab findings (normocytic anemia, reticulocytosis, increased RDW, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, negative Coombs test, and increased osmotic fragility) are consistent with hereditary spherocytosis, a condition where dacrocytes (teardrop-shaped red blood cells) are commonly seen on blood smear.

Dacrocytes are more commonly associated with myelofibrosis or other myeloproliferative disorders rather than hereditary spherocytosis, where spherocytes are the hallmark finding.
While spherocytes are the primary finding in hereditary spherocytosis, dacrocytes can occasionally be seen due to secondary bone marrow changes in chronic hemolysis.
The increased RDW and reticulocytosis could also be seen in thalassemia or other hemoglobinopathies, which would not typically show dacrocytes.
Thalassemia would typically show microcytic anemia with target cells rather than the normocytic anemia and spherocytes seen in this case.
The negative Coombs test doesn't completely rule out autoimmune hemolytic anemia, as some cases can be Coombs-negative and may present differently on smear.
Coombs-negative autoimmune hemolytic anemia would not explain the increased osmotic fragility or family history patterns typical of hereditary spherocytosis.
